title: Friday, 26th May, 2017
bodyHTML:
11:04 am
BE11:04am

Mercy, it's hot!

BE11:04am

BE11:05am

Apologies if we're dropped off air suddenly in the next hour.

11:05 am
BE11:05am

I'm "working from home" .......

BE11:06am

.... on a Lenovo R500 laptop running Vista, circa 2009 and bought off eBay for £50, that's shut down three times this morning already from overheating.

BE11:07am

If it all goes dark, that's why. Let's get on while we can.

11:07 am
BE11:07am

With an update from ....

BE11:07am

BE11:08am

(@pfd: massively, yes. I'm at serious risk if haxx0rz ever want my mp3 collection of mid-90s house music.)

11:08 am
BE11:08am

The needlework credit goes once again to SirSandGoblin, from the Twitter dot com microblogging website.

BE11:08am

https://twitter.com/SirSandGoblin

BE11:09am

Sterling off 0.4% or thereabouts last I checked.

11:09 am
BE11:09am

Post the YouGov poll for the Times (done over 24-25 May) showing the Conservatives as holding just a 5% lead over Labour, at 43% to 38%.

BE11:09am

Smallest lead for the Tories since May became PM back in July.

BE11:10am

(@Patience: already ahead of you. It's balanced on a copy of Joan Didion's The Last Thing He Wanted.)

11:11 am
BE11:11am

Yougov's last poll put the Tories on a 9% lead, FWIW.

BE11:11am

The breakdown is also vaguely interesting.

BE11:12am

Brexit continues to be the most important issue for voters (56%) followed by health (41%), immigration & asylum (37%), defense & security
(34%), and the economy (28%). Meanwhile, Theresa May receives a net score of +25pp for people trusting her to make the right decisions about keeping Britain safe from terrorism compared to -18pp for Jeremy Corbyn.

11:12 am
BE11:12am

Isn't Brexit all those things tho?

BE11:13am

Isn't it like saying "education and health are important of course, but the thing I'm most worried about is the the space-time continuum."

BE11:13am

Anyway, want to hear some FX traders talking about politics as if they know?

11:13 am
BE11:13am

That's always fun, right? Here's Citi.

BE11:14am

we think this is probably due to the Labour manifesto making generous welfare and investment promises compared to the Conservatives’ mix of moderate market interventions and spending increases funded by welfare cuts and potential tax hikes. Although Jeremy Corbyn’s popularity ratings have been improving, the gap between him and Theresa May continues to be substantial on numerous issues which is likely to cap how much Labour can catch up in the polls. We maintain our base case of a large Conservative victory, but the margin may be less than first anticipated (see UK
Economics & Strategy View - UK Elections: Expect Big Tory Victory to Cap Tail Risks (& Chances)). PM Theresa May will most likely gain enough seats in the election to reduce her dependence on the fringes of her party in terms of Brexit negotiations, but greater resistance within her party could emerge on some domestic issues.

BE11:14am

Morgan Stanley as well.

11:14 am
BE11:14am

GBP turns sour. Earlier this year, we converted to GBP bulls, citing cheap
valuation, extreme short positioning, a projected improvement in the UK’s current
account position and markets' over-bearishness on the outcome of Brexit
negotiations. However, over recent days, the outlook for GBP has markedly
weakened and there is now the risk of GBPUSD breaking the 1.2850 support,
which would confirm that a medium-term top has been traded near 1.3050 last
week. The Q1 GDP report did not only surprise with its weak 0.2%Q headline
print; it also revealed weakness within its composition such as the support from
government spending which surged 0.8%Q. Budget data revealed a slump in VAT
revenues, confirming a slowdown in final domestic demand. It seems that the
cyclical position of GBP has weakened.
UK politics. Not boding well for GBP has been the recent sharp decline in the
Conservative Party lead in opinion polls. YouGov now has the Conservatives at
43% and Labour at 38%. Obviously, the Conservatives election manifesto did not
find the hoped-for support, and what was seen as a U-turn on social policies
made investors question the strength of the government's backbone in upcoming
Brexit negotiations. The EU presenting a high exit bill suggests a tough start to
the exit talks starting next month. Given all these risks, the current GBP yield
compensation does not seem high enough, suggesting GBP will weaken.

BE11:15am

Or if you prefer, there's the Times's Red Box email. https://www.thetim...p-redbox-925pqzzpj

BE11:15am

Which is pretty good.

11:15 am
BE11:15am

undefined
BE11:16am

So anyway, FTSE up a tad because sterling.

11:18 am
BE11:18am

(@littleclenches: Kleinmanator's been on that story like glue for the past few months, and kudos to him for tenacity. However, while I'm sure the fate of an unlisted tobacco distributor is thrilling to someone, but I'm not that someone.)

BE11:18am

News is typically Friday. Not much around.

BE11:19am

Restaurant Group's probably the most interesting, though YMMV.

11:19 am
Restaurant Group PLC (RTN:LSE): Last: 346.85, up 29.45 (+9.28%), High: 362.70, Low: 342.80, Volume: 3.86m
BE11:20am

It's not quite as terrible as we'd been softened to expect.

BE11:20am

LFL sales for the first 20 weeks of the year
at -1.8%.

11:20 am
BE11:20am

Forecasts were for 4%ish.

BE11:21am

How much of this is just noise in the figures? Hard to say.

BE11:21am

It's certainly not the new menus tho. RTN doesn't even try to claim that.

11:21 am
BE11:21am

Here's Caz.

BE11:21am

In the first 20 weeks of 2017 to 21 May, TRG saw a
1.5% decline in sales, with a LFL decline of 1.8%. The three tailwinds that have supported sales are: (1) Strong growth in UK passenger numbers as a result of increased airline capacity, which has boosted the performance of the Concessions business; (2) Good weather, especially in April and late May, which has supported the Pubs business; and (3) Strong cinema admissions, which have helped the Leisure business.

BE11:22am

So, while this is all one-off stuff, the shares have probably fallen enough based on stabilising alone.

11:22 am
BE11:22am

That's Caz's thesis. Not mine.

BE11:23am

An important part of the strategy for recovery
at TRG is investment in the pricing of its menus, especially in its Leisure
formats. A new menu was introduced in Frankie & Benny’s earlier this
month, with reduced prices that will have an immediate effect on LFL
sales through the balance of the year (but did not really affect LFLs in
the first 20 weeks). We expect increased discounting activity over the
rest of the year too. Finally, the favourable tailwinds of the first 20 weeks
cannot be assumed to continue at the same pace. The second half will see
an annualisation of increased airline capacity and cinema admissions are
likely to moderate over the next few months (although a strong end to the
year seems likely given the next installment of the Star Wars series)

BE11:23am

But, we now see upside to the share price. Shares in TRG have lost
17% since 10 March. FY18E EV/EBITDA is now 6.7x with a FCF yield
of 7.6% and a dividend yield of 5.5% (on our unchanged estimates).
Despite the risks, this appears too cheap to us and we upgrade as a result.

11:23 am
BE11:23am

Citi also buyers.

BE11:23am

Management expects that the positive drivers (PAX, Cinema
attendance) will moderate as the year progresses. RTN continues to invest in the
business to support the turnaround but there is no real colour on the early impact of
recent menu changes which will be critical to delivering a sustained recovery.
Nevertheless the FY17E PBT outlook is unchanged. We expect no change to
consensus PBT of £56m (Citi £56m). Our LFL forecasts for the remainder of the
year are Q3 -2%, Q4 +0%.

BE11:24am

We have a Buy recommendation for three reasons: 1) Our
FY17 margin assumption at 8.6% is now in line with the prior trough in 2001
(8.6%). 2) Financial leverage remains very low (FY17E ND/EBITDA 0.4x), which
should minimise the risk of financial distress. 3) We expect cash generation to
remain strong which should comfortably support the c5% dividend yield.
Importantly we have yet to bake into our forecasts any significant increase in
EBIT margins beyond FY17.

11:24 am
BE11:24am

Numis, also buyers.

BE11:24am

Outlook and Forecasts: We are mindful that the full impact of the F&B menu is yet to
be felt and our forecasts are therefore unchanged. That said, YTD trading is better than
expected and comparators gradually become less demanding. Note that each 1ppt on lfls
is worth c.10% on EPS, other things being equal.
Buying opportunity, P/E 13.6x, 5.5% yield: In our view RTN has strong management,
a solid balance sheet and attractive FCF. We expect the turnaround in lfls to take time
(hence our assumption of -4%) and cost pressures industry-wide mean margins are
unlikely to return to previous peak (13%) near term. However, the bear case assumes lfls
remain weak and our DCF suggests the stock is currently discounting a margin of 8% in
perpetuity. This creates a compelling entry point on a credible recovery story.

BE11:26am

UBS, sellers.

11:26 am
BE11:26am

Though not for reasons beyond the ones already discussed. Menu engineering and stuff. See a couple of days ago.

undefined
BE11:27am

ROTR, The Ned? Really?

11:27 am
BE11:27am

Soho House is just a Harvester for people on six-figure salaries.

BE11:28am

And it's gradually blandifying every city in the world.

BE11:29am

Who remembers a night at Soho House? It's so damn ordinary, comfortable, dull. I mean, unless you like looking at the guys they pay to swim in the pool at the Shoreditch one ... and if that's your thing, fine.

11:30 am
BE11:30am

But there are cheaper, better, more dignified ways to do that. Personally, I can't be doing with all that slate grey cotton and negronis in too-small glasses.

BE11:30am

Okay, back on topic.

Batm Advanced Communications Ltd (BVC:LSE): Last: 18.43, up 0.055 (+0.30%), Volume: 25.00k
11:31 am
BE11:31am

Pepsi's out.

BE11:31am

DAMN! Sorry, wrong ticker.

Britvic PLC (BVIC:LSE): Last: 697.50, down 25.5 (-3.53%), High: 712.00, Low: 694.00, Volume: 1.87m
11:32 am
BE11:32am

Pepsi's not invested in Batm. That'd be sensational.

BE11:32am

695p, 4% below market.

BE11:34am

That coincides with a fair bit of results comment, mostly saying "it's run too far"

11:35 am
BE11:35am

Citi, I think, as still buyers.

BE11:04am

Too hot.

BE11:35am

 Pepsi placement — On 25/5 Pepsi announced it would sell its 4.5% stake in
Britvic. We this this largely as a cleaning up exercise to improve Pepsi’s capital
efficiency. The value of the stake is minuscule in the context of PEP (less than 0.1%
of its market cap). Selling the stake has no impact, in our opinion, on the strong
relationship between the two companies. Worth noting that (1) the GB bottling
agreement stretches until 2028 and the value of the bottling franchise rights on
Britvic’s balance sheet assumes a remaining useful life of 26 years, “on the basis
that the renewal of the franchise agreements is highly probable”; (2) Pepsi and
Britvic have just conducted quite a significant new product launch in GB (Pepsi Max
Ginger). Moreover, the fact that Pepsi is selling the stake has no impact on its right
to pull its brands, in the event of a change in control of Britvic.

11:36 am
BE11:36am

And Goodbody, to reiterate that it's probably irrelevant.

BE11:36am

This was a passive investment for Pepsico which it has owned since Britvic’s IPO in 2006. At
this stage, Pepsico has taken the opportunity to free up c.£85m to reinvest behind its own
consolidated business/brands.
Britvic’s bottling agreement with Pepsico in GB runs until 2023 while the agreement in
Ireland was renewed in Jan-16 for another 10 years. Britvic has done an excellent job for
Pepsi in the UK, driven by Pepsi Max, and it has a good reverse relationship with Pepsi
bottlers in the US.
Overall we expect this will have no impact on the Group and remain positive on the
stock given: i) its portfolio bias to lower sugar products; ii) the extensive cost
savings programme; and iii) international growth opportunities.

BE11:38am

Oh, Dom Walsh in the Times this morning mentions Britvic's attempt to FeverTree.

11:38 am
BE11:38am

Under the "London Essence Company" brand.

BE11:39am

Interestingly, the selling point is that it's more expensive.

BE11:39am

"a 15 to 20 per cent premium to Fevertree tonic".

11:39 am
BE11:40am

Soda water as a Veblen good. Well done everyone.

undefined
BE11:41am

Someone highlighted to me recently that we've not touched on Gemfields.

11:40 am
Gemfields PLC (GEM:LSE): Last: 34.00, up 0.25 (+0.74%), High: 34.00, Low: 34.00, Volume: 65.76k
BE11:41am

On the Pallinghurst takeover.

BE11:41am

Which has created a great deal of anger and such.

11:42 am
BE11:42am

A reminder that Pallinghust has 47.1%, has the backing of a further 27%, so needs to take out the 28.2%

BE11:44am

Numis has a walk through the deal this morning, concluding "this is bad but what to do? [shrug]".

BE11:44am

. We view the offer as opportunistic
and not reflective of GEM's underlying value however it appears that options are
limited for GEM's minority shareholders. As such, we reduce our recommendation
to HOLD from BUY and our target price to 36p/sh based on the current bid market
value. However, we believe that fair value would be nearer our 94p/sh NAV estimate.

11:44 am
BE11:45am

● Offer well below fair value for GEM: We currently estimate GEM's net asset value at
94p/sh. This includes US$400m (57p/sh) for Kagem, US$317m (45p/sh) for Montepuez
and US$112m (14p) of inventory, as reported as at 31 December 2016. Even were we
to strip out our US$100m valuation for Faberge, we would generate an NAV of 80p/
share for GEM. Based on the close price on 17 May, PGL's offer values GEM at 38.5p/
sh or ú211.45m, less than half of our estimate NAV. Based on current prices and FX
rates at the time of writing, the offer is now valued at 36p/sh or ú197m (~US$256m) and
GEM shares are trading at 33.5p/sh, indicating shareholder resignation to the prospect
of holding PGL shares. The bid comes as GEM has moved through a difficult period
initiated by the Indian demonetisation programme, which had a significant (but in our
view temporary) disruptive effect on the emerald market. With only one auction of high
quality emeralds in FY17, we believe that GEM's shares were depressed relative to
their prior trading range and to fair value. We believe that GEM shareholders should
vote against the transaction, which is undervalued, opportunistic and at nil premium

BE11:45am

Options for minority shareholders appear limited: The offer is not currently
irrevocable as to acceptances, as acceptances can be made only after the Offer
Document has been posted by PGL. At such time, the offer is expected to become
irrevocable. Without a natural white knight in the sector, we view a withdrawal of the
offer by PGL as the primary plausible scenario in which the deal would not go forward.

BE11:45am

Okay, so here's what I've never quite understood about Gemfields.

11:46 am
BE11:46am

Gemfields borrows money against the value of its inventory, which is fine. That's a perfectly reasonable way to run a shiny stone business.

BE11:46am

Its inventory is through the books at $107m or thereabouts.

BE11:47am

Of that, the Faberge inventory is in there at $40.8m.

11:47 am
BE11:47am

But Faberge's weird. It does basically no sales.

BE11:47am

You're looking at $8m-ish revenue a year for the past few years.

BE11:47am

That's a very slow stock turn, even for a trinket seller.

11:47 am
BE11:47am

Theo Fennell, to take a random example, was doing £12m in annual sales and reported about £6m of stock. So, (in theory) it turns over its entire inventory every six months.

BE11:48am

Why does Faberge has so much stuff locked in its storeroom? Why, based on a surface reading of the figures, is it turning over its entire inventory every five years!

BE11:48am

And how do you accurately value a retailer's inventory except on the value at which it'll sell? How's that possible with such a slow stock turn? It's odd.

11:48 am
BE11:49am

Did I mention Gemfields borrows money against the value of its inventory? I did? Okay. Cool.

undefined
BE11:50am

What else? Can't think. Too hot.

11:51 am
BE11:52am

Have we wrapped up sellside?

BE11:52am

There's a Redburn note around in Tate & Lyle but no-one's sent me it yet.

Tate & Lyle PLC (TATE:LSE): Last: 727.00, down 22 (-2.94%), High: 747.50, Low: 722.00, Volume: 1.20m
11:53 am
BE11:53am

And a Merrill note on oil, but no-one's sent me it yet.

BE11:54am

Wait, I did have a one-par sum there.

BE11:54am

With another OPEC meeting behind us, we revisit E&P sector preferences in the context of a range bound oil price. Having recently underperformed the sector, we double upgrade Cairn Energy to Buy; meanwhile we downgrade PMO, DNO, GENEL. The sector is trading at an 6% discount to NAV, and pricing in a long-term oil price of US$62/boe, ranging from US$40-75/boe.

11:53 am
Premier Oil PLC (PMO:LSE): Last: 60.17, down 2.58 (-4.12%), High: 61.25, Low: 60.00, Volume: 3.01m
Cairn Energy PLC (CNE:LSE): Last: 211.20, up 0.2 (+0.09%), High: 217.00, Low: 211.00, Volume: 560.65k
BE11:55am

.... welcome to Mifid II. If you remind people they're actually paying for stuff, they hoard it.

11:55 am
BE11:55am

There's also Experian.

Experian PLC (EXPN:LSE): Last: 1,637, down 9 (-0.55%), High: 1,640, Low: 1,603, Volume: 1.09m
BE11:56am

Deutsche negative.

11:56 am
BE11:56am

Very similar argument to Kean at Jefferies a few days ago.

BE11:56am

We believe the current valuation does not factor in likely slowing US
employment growth, consumer deleveraging and structural pressure on the
Consumer Services divisional margin. Sell.

BE11:57am

Experian trades at an all-time high fwd 12m P/E multiple and yet we believe
the outlook for top line growth and margin is weakening. US consumer credit
growth is a function of employment and we believe employment growth will
slow in 17e into 18e. At the same time we expect the US consumer will have
to de-lever which will further limit growth. A lack of operational gearing in the
US business may hold back growth investment or the company. At the same
time we see Group margin risk largely due to Consumer Services.

11:57 am
BE11:57am

We are cutting our Mar 18e EPS by 7% and Mar 19e EPS by 6%. This reflects
lower organic assumptions, the sale of email/CCM and the announced share
buyback. We reduce our target price to 1460p.

BE11:57am

Our target price is DCF derived using a 7.2% WACC derived from a 4% risk
free rate, 4% equity risk premium and 1.0x beta. Upside risks to our negative
stance include better GDP growth and greater consumer leverage than we
forecast especially in the US, UK & Brazil, margin upside from mix benefits,
operational gearing and productivity measures and higher organic growth from
new product launches. Lower US corporate tax rates and M&A are also
sources of upside risk.

undefined
11:58 am
BE11:58am

@Soundbuy: asking around re Countryside.

Countryside Properties PLC (CSP:LSE): Last: 307.30, up 4.3 (+1.42%), High: 309.70, Low: 300.30, Volume: 104.40m
BE12:00pm

Can't see the trade immediately on the Time and Sales page.

12:00 pm
BE12:00pm

Ah, there it is. 32m shares at 310p.

BE12:00pm

11.28am.

BE12:01pm

Oaktree and Aviva both have that amount or more.

12:01 pm
BE12:02pm

Both have been sellers, Oaktree recently slotting 45m.

BE12:02pm

It's speculation but one would assume they're supply. ....... wait ........

BE12:03pm

Thank you @Michael .....

12:03 pm
BE12:03pm

So, Numis did the job.

BE12:03pm

26 May 2017

Oaktree announces that the Seller has sold 103,686,504 ordinary shares at a price of 310 pence per share in Countryside (representing approximately 23.0% of the Company's issued share capital) (the "Placing") through Numis Securities Limited ("Numis").

Following completion of the Placing, the Seller will continue to hold 103,686,505 ordinary shares in the Company, representing approximately 23.0% of the issued share capital of the Company. These shares are subject to a lock-up which ends 180 days after completion of the Placing (subject to waiver by Numis and to certain exceptions).

The proceeds of the Placing are payable in cash on usual settlement terms, and settlement of the Placing is expected to occur on a T+2 basis on 31 May 2017.

The Company will not receive any proceeds from the Placing.

Following completion of the Placing, Oaktree's representative, Jim Van Steenkiste (Non-Executive Director) will be stepping down from the Company's board of directors.

BE12:04pm

Placing at premium that was kept on the downlow? Coo. Well done Numis.

12:04 pm
undefined
BE12:05pm

Okay, we're done for the well.

BE12:05pm

Thanks to my laptop for somehow getting through the last hour without expiring.

12:05 pm
BE12:06pm

Ditto you, reader.

BE12:06pm

Afternoon all.

BE11:35am

 Strong H1 — Britvic delivered another strong set of results, with org sales, EBITA
and EPS all well ahead of expectations. EBITA increased 5% organically, which
stands out well, even in the broader consumer staples sector. Cost savings are on
track, the innovation pipeline for 2H looks strong (Robinsons REFRESH’D ready-todrink) and management seems confident about the FY outlook. We are raising EPS
1 -1.5%, and we believe there could be some further upside to forecasts.
 We have raised EPS 1 -1.5% — The upgrade reflects the stronger than expected
H1. We haven’t raised FY17 ests by more, because part of the H1 “beat” relates to
A&P phasing. Our forecasts could be conservative we believe, as they assume only
flat 2H EBITA, despite (a) further cost savings, (b) c£2m benefit from FX and scope,
and (c) revenue mgt initiatives in GB which should mitigate margin pressures in 2H.
 Buy, target raised 810p — H1 results confirm Britvic has enough self-help (cost
savings and revenue mgt flexibility) to deliver good growth even in a challenging
environment. Moreover, some of the recent innovation (e.g. stretching Robinsons
into adjacent categories) and revenue mgt initiatives (enabled by enhanced
manufacturing flexibility), show that Britvic is really evolving from the company it
was a few years ago. Our new target price assumes a slight rerating of the stock in
the next 12 months to about 16x 12-m forward PE, c25% discount to EU staples
